text: After the death of Joshua, the children of Israel inquired of the Lord, “Who should go up against the Canaanites first, in order to wage war against them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Judah shall go up. Indeed, I have given the land into their hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Judah said to Simeon, their brothers, “Come up with us into our allotted territory. We will wage war against the Canaanites. Likewise we will go with you into your allotted territory.” So Simeon went with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah went up, and the Lord gave the Canaanites and Perizzites into their hands. They struck down ten thousand men in Bezek.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found Adoni-Bezek in Bezek and fought against him. They struck down the Canaanites and Perizzites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Adoni-Bezek fled, and they chased after him, seized him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoni-Bezek said, “Seventy kings whose thumbs and big toes were cut off once collected scraps of food under my table. Just as I have done, so God has repaid me.” They brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah waged war against Jerusalem. They captured it, struck it with the edge of the sword, and sent the city up in flames.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, Judah went down to wage war against the Canaanites living in the hill country, the Negev, and the lowlands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah went against the Canaanites living in Hebron (previously the name of Hebron was Kiriath Arba) and they struck down Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they went against the inhabitants of Debir (previously the name of Debir was Kiriath Sepher).
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb said, “He who attacks Kiriath Sepher and takes it, I will give him my daughter Aksah as wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Othniel son of Kenaz, the younger brother of Caleb, captured it. So Caleb gave him Aksah his daughter in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she came to Othniel, she urged him to ask her father for a field. As she dismounted from her donkey, Caleb said to her, “What can I do for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She answered, “Please give me a special gift. Since you have given me land in the Negev, now give me springs of water.” So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Moses’ father-in-law, the Kenite, went up with the descendants of Judah from the City of Palms to the Negev near Arad. Then they went and lived with the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Judah went with his brother Simeon and struck down the Canaanites living in Zephath and utterly destroyed it. So now they call the city Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah captured Gaza, Ashkelon, Ekron, and the territory belonging to each of these cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Judah, and they took the hill country but could not drive out the inhabitants of the coastal plain, for they had iron chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave Hebron to Caleb, as Moses had said, and he drove out the three sons of Anak.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the tribe of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites living in Jerusalem, so the Jebusites live with the tribe of Benjamin in Jerusalem to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph went up against Bethel, and the Lord was with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph sent spies into Bethel (the former name of the city was Luz).
speaker: Narrator

text: The spies saw a man coming out of the city and said to him, “Please show us the entrance to the city, and we will deal kindly with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he showed them an entrance to the city. They struck the city with the edge of the sword, but they let the man and his extended family go.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man went to the land of the Hittites. He built a city and named it Luz, and that is its name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth Shan, Taanach, Dor, Ibleam, Megiddo, or their daughter villages, for the Canaanites were determined to live in that land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the children of Israel became strong, they put the Canaanites to hard labor as slaves, but they did not actually drive them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephraim did not drive out the inhabitants of Gezer, so the Canaanites lived among them in Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron and Nahalol, so the Canaanites lived among them and became slave laborers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Akko, Sidon, Ahlab, Akzib, Helbah, Aphek, or Rehob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, for they did not drive them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naphtali did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth Shemesh or Beth Anath, so they live among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land. The Canaanites of Beth Shemesh and Beth Anath became slave laborers for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites pushed the tribe of Dan into the hill country, for they would not let them come down to the coastal plain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites were determined to live in Mount Heres, Aijalon, and Shaalbim, but the hand of the descendants of Joseph was heavy on them, and they became slave laborers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border of the Amorites was from the Ascent of Akrabbim to Sela and beyond.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord went up from Gilgal to Bokim and said, “I brought you up from Egypt and brought you into the land that I promised your fathers. I said, ‘I will never break My covenant with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you must not make a pact with the inhabitants of this land, and you must tear down their altars.’ Yet you have not obeyed Me. What is this you have done?
speaker: Narrator

text: So now I say, ‘I will not drive them out before you. They will be thorns in your sides, and their gods will be a snare to you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel of the Lord spoke these words to all the children of Israel, the people raised their voices and wept aloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: They named that place Bokim and sacrificed to the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua dismissed the people, each Israelite went to his inheritance to possess the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people served the Lord all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua, who had seen all the great works that the Lord had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died at the age of one hundred and ten.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried him in the territory of his inheritance in Timnath Heres, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
speaker: Narrator

text: That entire generation passed away, and after them grew up a generation who did not know the Lord or the deeds that He had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord and served the Baals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They abandoned the Lord God of their fathers, who brought them out of the land of Egypt. They followed after other gods, the gods of the peoples around them. They worshipped them and provoked the Lord to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: They abandoned the Lord and served Baal and the Ashtoreths.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and He gave them into the hands of those who plundered them; and He sold them into the hands of their enemies around them, so that they were no longer able to stand against their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they marched out, the hand of the Lord was against them to bring disaster, as the Lord had said and as He had sworn to them. They were in great distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord raised up judges who delivered them from the hand of those who plundered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they would not listen to their judges, for they prostituted themselves to other gods and worshipped them. They quickly turned aside from the path their fathers had walked, who had obeyed the commandments of the Lord. They did not do as their fathers had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord raised up judges for them, the Lord was with the judge and delivered them from the hand of their enemies all the days of the judge; for their groaning before their oppressors and tormentors grieved the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the judge died, the people turned back and acted more wickedly than their fathers, pursuing other gods to serve and worship them. They would not give up their practices and obstinate ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and He said, “Because this nation has violated My covenant that I commanded their fathers and has not heeded My voice,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will no longer drive out from before them any of the nations that Joshua left when he died,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that through them I may test Israel and see whether or not they will keep the ways of the Lord, to walk in them as their fathers did.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord left those nations, not hurrying to drive them out; and He did not deliver them into the hand of Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the nations that the Lord left to test those in Israel who had not experienced war in Canaan
speaker: Narrator

text: (so that later generations of the children of Israel who did not know war before might know it, to teach them how to fight):
speaker: Narrator

text: the five Philistine lords, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites living on Mount Lebanon, from Mount Baal Hermon to Lebo Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were to test Israel, in order to know if they would obey the commandments of the Lord, which He commanded their fathers by the hand of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their daughters for themselves as wives, and gave their own daughters to their sons, and served their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the Lord. They forgot the Lord their God and served the Baals and the Asherahs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and He sold them into the hands of Cushan-Rishathaim, king of Mesopotamia. The children of Israel served Cushan-Rishathaim for eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the children of Israel cried out to the Lord, and the Lord raised up a deliverer in order to save the children of Israel—Othniel son of Kenaz, the younger brother of Caleb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord came on him, and he judged Israel. He went out to battle, and the Lord gave Cushan-Rishathaim, king of Mesopotamia, into his hands, so that Othniel overpowered Cushan-Rishathaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land rested forty years, then Othniel son of Kenaz died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the children of Israel once more did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, so the Lord strengthened King Eglon of Moab against Israel because they had done what was evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eglon joined forces with the Ammonites and Amalekites; then he went and attacked Israel and took possession of the City of Palms.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel served King Eglon of Moab for eighteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the children of Israel cried out to the Lord, and the Lord raised up a deliverer—Ehud son of Gera the Benjamite, a left-handed man. The children of Israel sent a tribute payment by him to King Eglon of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud made a cubit-long two-edged sword for himself and strapped it onto his right thigh under his cloak.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the tribute payment to King Eglon of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ehud finished offering the tribute payment, he sent away the people who carried it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he himself turned back from the stone idols that were at Gilgal, and said, “I have a secret message for you, O king.”
And he said, “Keep silence!” And all who attended him departed from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud approached him as he was sitting alone in his cool upper chamber. Ehud said, “I have a message from God for you.” And Eglon rose from his seat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ehud reached with his left hand, drew the sword from his right thigh, and plunged it into the belly of Eglon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hilt went in after the blade and the fat closed over the blade and his entrails came out, for he did not pull the sword out of the belly of Eglon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ehud went out to the entrance hall and closed the doors of the upper chamber on him and locked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he went out, the servants of Eglon came. They looked and noticed the doors of the upper chamber were locked. They thought, “Surely he is attending to his needs in the cool chamber.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They waited until they were embarrassed, but he still did not open the doors of the upper chamber. So they took a key and opened it. There, fallen dead on the floor, was their lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Ehud escaped while they were waiting. He passed the sacred stones and escaped to Seirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Upon his arrival, he blew a ram’s horn trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim. Then the children of Israel went down with him from the hill country, and he led them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Follow me, for the Lord has given your enemies the Moabites into your hands.” They followed him, and they captured the Jordan fords leading to Moab. They did not let anyone cross.
speaker: Narrator

text: They struck down about ten thousand Moabites, all strong and valorous men, and not a single man escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moab was humbled under the hand of Israel that day, and the land had peace for eighty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Ehud was Shamgar son of Anath. He struck down six hundred Philistine men with an ox goad. He also saved Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ehud was dead, the children of Israel once more did what was evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sold them into the hands of King Jabin of Canaan, who ruled in Hazor. The commander of his army was Sisera. He lived in Harosheth Haggoyim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel cried out to the Lord, for Sisera had nine hundred iron chariots and had forcefully oppressed the children of Israel for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Deborah, the wife of Lappidoth, was a prophetess. She judged Israel at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: She would sit under the palm tree of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim. The children of Israel would go up to her for her to render judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sent for Barak son of Abinoam from Kedesh in Naphtali and said to him, “The Lord God of Israel commands you, ‘Go and deploy troops at Mount Tabor, and take ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will draw Sisera, the commander of the army of Jabin, with his chariots and large army to you at the River Kishon and give him into your hands.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak said to her, “If you will go with me, then I will go, but if you will not go with me, then I will not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “I will indeed go with you. However, the way you are going will gain you no glory, for the Lord will deliver Sisera into the hand of a woman.” Then Deborah got up and went with Barak to Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak called Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh. Ten thousand men went up on foot with him, and Deborah went up with him also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Heber the Kenite had moved away from the Kenites, who were descendants of Hobab, Moses’ father-in-law. He pitched his tent at the oak in Zaanannim, near Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they told Sisera that Barak son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sisera summoned all his nine hundred iron chariots and all the people with him, from Harosheth Haggoyim to the River Kishon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Deborah said to Barak, “Get up, for this is the day that the Lord has given Sisera into your hands. Has not the Lord gone out before you?” So Barak went down from Mount Tabor with ten thousand men behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord routed Sisera and all of his chariots and all of his army with the edge of the sword in front of Barak. Sisera dismounted his chariot and fled on foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak chased after the chariots and the army as far as Harosheth Haggoyim. The whole army of Sisera fell by the edge of the sword. Not a single man survived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sisera fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between King Jabin of Hazor and the family of Heber the Kenite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, “Turn aside, my lord. Turn aside to me. Do not be afraid.” So he turned aside to her into the tent, and she covered him with a rug.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty.” So she opened a leather milk container, gave it to him to drink, and covered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “Stand in the entrance to the tent, and if anyone comes and asks you, ‘Is there a man here?’ then you say, ‘No.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jael the wife of Heber took a tent peg and a hammer in her hand and went quietly to him, for he was fast asleep and tired. She drove the tent peg into his temple, and it went down into the ground, so he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as Barak had been chasing Sisera, Jael came out to meet him and said, “Come, and I will show you the man whom you seek.” When he came in, there was Sisera fallen dead with a tent peg in his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God humbled King Jabin of Canaan before the children of Israel that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel grew more and more powerful over King Jabin of Canaan until he was no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day, Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When the leaders in Israel lead,
    when the people freely volunteer,
    bless the Lord!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Lord, when You went out from Seir,
    when You marched from the land of Edom,
the ground shook and the skies poured,
    indeed, the dense clouds poured water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountains quaked before the Lord,
    this very Sinai, before the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In the days of Shamgar son of Anath,
    in the days of Jael, main roads were abandoned
    and travelers used roundabout paths.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They were choosing new gods,
    and warfare was at the city gates,
but not a shield or spear was to be seen
    among forty thousand in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is with the rulers of Israel
    who offered themselves willingly among the people.
    Bless the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You who ride on white donkeys,
    you who sit in judges’ attire,
    you who walk on the road,
speaker: Narrator

text:
consider the voice of those who distribute water among the watering places.
    There they tell of the righteous deeds of the Lord,
    the righteous deeds of villagers in Israel. 
“Then the people of the Lord
    go down to the gates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, awake, Deborah!
    Awake, awake, sing a song!
Stand up, Barak,
    and capture your prisoners, son of Abinoam!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The survivors
    came down to the nobles;
the people of the Lord
    came down for me against the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some came from Ephraim, whose roots were in Amalek,
    following you, Benjamin, with your people.
From Makir rulers came down,
    and from Zebulun those who carry the staff of a scribe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes of Issachar were with Deborah,
    and Issachar was with Barak;
    they were sent into the valley on foot.
Among the clans of Reuben
    there was great resolve of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you sit among the sheepfolds
    to hear playing of pipes for the flocks?
In the clans of Reuben
    there was much searching of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan.
    As for Dan, why did he stay with the ships?
Asher stayed by the seacoast
    and settled by its bays.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zebulun is a people who risked their lives to the point of death,
    Naphtali also, on the heights of the battlefield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Kings came to wage war.
    The kings of Canaan waged war
in Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo;
    they took no money as profit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the heavens the stars fought,
    from their courses they fought against Sisera.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The torrent of Kishon swept them away,
    that ancient torrent, the torrent of Kishon.
    My soul, march on in strength!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then horses’ hooves pounded,
    the galloping, galloping of his steeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Curse Meroz, said the angel of the Lord,
    curse its inhabitants,
for they did not come to the aid of the Lord,
    to the aid of the Lord against the mighty warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Most blessed of women is Jael,
    the wife of Heber the Kenite,
    most blessed of tent-dwelling women.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked for water, she gave him milk.
    In a magnificent bowl she brought cream.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her hand on a tent peg,
    her right hand on a workman’s hammer;
she struck Sisera, she crushed his skull,
    she shattered and pierced his temple.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“The mother of Sisera looked through the window,
    and cried out through the lattice,
‘Why is his chariot so late?
    Why is the sound of his war chariots so delayed?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her wise attendants answered her,
    indeed, she replied to herself,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Are they not finding and dividing the spoils:
    a girl or two for each man;
dyed garments as plunder for Sisera,
    dyed and embroidered garments,
two pieces of dyed embroidery for the neck of the looter?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“May all Your enemies perish like this, O Lord!
    But may those who love Him rise like the sun
    when it rises in full strength.”
Then the land was at peace for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord, so the Lord gave them into the hands of Midian for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hands of Midian dominated Israel, and because of Midian the children of Israel made hiding places for themselves in the mountains, caves, and strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever Israel would plant crops, the Midianites, Amalekites, and the people from the east would come up against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they would make camp by them and ruin crops of the land all the way to Gaza. They did not leave any provisions behind in Israel—neither sheep, nor cattle, nor donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they came with their livestock and tents like a swarm of locusts. They and their camels were too numerous to count, and they came into the land to destroy it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel was made weak before Midian and cried out to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the children of Israel cried out to the Lord because of Midian,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord sent them a prophet who said, “Thus says the Lord God of Israel: I brought you up from Egypt and out of that place of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: I delivered you from the hands of Egypt and all your oppressors. I drove them out from before you and gave you their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to you, ‘I am the Lord your God. Do not worship the gods of the Amorites in whose land you are living.’ But you have disobeyed Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the angel of the Lord came and sat under the oak tree in Ophrah belonging to Joash the Abiezrite. Gideon his son was threshing wheat in a winepress to hide it from the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord appeared and said to him, “The Lord is with you, O mighty man of valor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to him, “O my lord, if the Lord is with us, then why has all this happened to us? Where are all His miracles that our fathers told us about? They said, ‘Did not the Lord bring us out of Egypt?’ Yet now the Lord has forsaken us and delivered us into the hands of the Midianites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord turned to him and said, “Go in this strength of yours. Save Israel from the control of Midian. Have I not sent you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to Him, “O my Lord, how can I save Israel? Indeed my clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the youngest in my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “But I will be with you, and you will strike the Midianites as one man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to Him, “If I have found favor in Your sight, give me a sign that it is You who are speaking with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please do not depart from here until I come to You and bring out my gift and set it before You.”
And He said, “I will stay until you return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon went and prepared a young goat and unleavened bread from an ephah of flour. He put the meat in a basket, and he put the broth in a pot, and brought them out and offered them to Him under the oak.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the angel of God said to him, “Take the meat and the unleavened bread, lay them on this rock, and pour out the broth.” And so he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord reached out the tip of the staff that was in His hand and touched the meat and unleavened flatbread. Fire rose out of the rock and consumed the meat and unleavened bread. Then the angel of the Lord departed from his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon perceived that it was indeed the angel of the Lord. So Gideon said, “Alas, O Lord God! I have seen the angel of the Lord face to face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “Peace be with you. Do not be afraid. You will not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon built an altar for the Lord there and called it The Lord Is Peace. Even to this day it stands in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night the Lord said to him, “Take a bull from your father’s herd and a second bull seven years old. Tear down your father’s Baal altar and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then build an altar to the Lord your God on top of this stronghold in an orderly way. Take the second bull and offer it as a burnt offering with the wood of the Asherah pole that you will cut down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon took ten men from among his slaves and did as the Lord had told him, but because he was too afraid of the rest of his father’s household and the men of the city to do it by day, he did it at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of the city got up early in the morning, the altar of Baal was torn down, the Asherah pole beside it was cut down, and the second bull had been offered on the new altar that had been built.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to each other, “Who has done this?”
When they had inquired and asked, they responded, “Gideon son of Joash has done this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of the city said to Joash, “Bring out your son so that he may die, for he tore down the altar of Baal and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash then said to all who stood against him, “Would you plead for Baal? Would you save him? Whoever fights for him will be killed by morning. If Baal is a god, let him fight for himself, for someone has torn down his altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore on that day he called him Jerub-Baal, saying, “Let Baal fight him, for he tore down the altar of Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Midianites, Amalekites, and the people from the east gathered together, and they crossed over, and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord enveloped Gideon. He blew a ram’s horn trumpet, and the Abiezrites assembled behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers throughout all of Manasseh and they assembled behind him as well. He also sent messengers to Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, so these tribes came up to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said to God, “If You will use my hands to save Israel, as You have said—
speaker: Narrator

text: I am placing a fleece of wool on the threshing floor. If there is dew on the fleece only and all of the ground remains dry, then I will know that You will save Israel with my hands, as You have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it happened. He got up early the next morning and squeezed the fleece. Enough dew poured out of the fleece to fill a bowlful of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to God, “Do not let Your anger burn against me as I speak only one more time. Please let me perform a test with the fleece one more time. Please, let the fleece be the only thing dry, and let there be dew on all of the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God did this during that night. Only the fleece was dry, and the dew was on all the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) and all the people who were with him got up early and set up camp at Harod Spring. There was a camp of Midianites to the north of them in the valley near the hill of Moreh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Gideon, “You have too many people with you for Me to give the Midianites into their hands, lest Israel glorify themselves over Me, saying, ‘Our own power saved us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, call out so the people can hear, ‘Whoever is afraid or anxious may turn back and leave Mount Gilead.’ ” So twenty-two thousand from among the people turned back, and ten thousand were left.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Gideon, “There are still too many people. Bring them down to the water, and I will test them for you there. When I say to you, ‘This one will go with you,’ he will go with you. Everyone about whom I will say, ‘This one will not go with you,’ will not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought the people down to the water, and the Lord said to Gideon, “You shall set apart by himself everyone who laps the water with his tongue like dogs; likewise, everyone who kneels down to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of those who lapped, putting their hands to their mouths, was three hundred. The rest of the people had knelt to drink water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Gideon, “With three hundred men who lapped to drink, I will save you and give the Midianites into your hands. All the rest of the people should go home.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the three hundred men took provisions and ram’s horn trumpets in their hands. Gideon sent all the other Israelite men to their tents, but he kept the three hundred men.
Now the Midianite camp was below him in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night the Lord said to him, “Get up and go down into the camp, for I have given it into your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet if you are afraid to go down, then go down to the camp with Purah your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to what they say, and afterward you will be emboldened to go down to the camp.” So he and Purah his servant went down near the edge of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Midianites, Amalekites, and the Kedemites covered the valley like locusts; and their camels could not be counted, for they were as numerous as grains of sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon came and overheard one man who was telling his dream to another. The man said, “Listen to a dream I had. I saw a dry cake of barley bread rolling into the Midianite camp. It rolled up to a tent and struck it. It fell, turned upside down, and collapsed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The other man responded, “This is none other than the sword of Gideon son of Joash the Israelite. God has given Midian and the whole camp into his hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon heard the telling of the dream and its interpretation, he worshipped, returned to the camp of Israel, and said, “Get up, for the Lord has given the Midianite camp into your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He divided the three hundred men into three combat units. He gave all of them ram’s horn trumpets, empty jars, and torches within the jars.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Look at me and do likewise. Watch, and when I come to the perimeter of the camp, do as I do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I and all who are with me blow the horn, then you will blow the horns all around the camp and shout, ‘For the Lord and for Gideon!’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon and a hundred men with him went to the edge of the camp at the start of the middle night watch, just as they were setting the watch. Then they blew the horns and smashed the jars in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three combat units blew the horns and broke the jars. They held the torches in their left hands and the horns for blowing in their right hands. They called out, “A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man stood in his place all around the camp, but the men in the camp ran, shouted, and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they blew the three hundred horns, the Lord turned every man’s sword against his fellow man throughout the camp. The Midianite camp fled to Beth Shittah in the direction of Zererah, up to the border of Abel Meholah, near Tabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel from Naphtali, Asher, and all of Manasseh were summoned, and they chased after the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now Gideon sent messengers throughout the hill country of Ephraim, saying, “Come down to engage Midian in battle. Take control of the water ways as far as Beth Barah and the Jordan.”
All the men of Ephraim were summoned, and they took control of the water ways as far as Beth Barah and the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They captured Oreb and Zeeb, the two Midianite commanders. They killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb and killed Zeeb at the winepress of Zeeb. They chased after the Midianites and brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon on the other side of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Ephraim said to him, “What have you done to us by not calling us to go and wage war against Midian?” They argued heatedly with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “What have I done now compared to you? Are not the gleanings of the grapes of Ephraim better than the harvest of Abiezer?
speaker: Narrator

text: It was into your hands that God gave the Midianite commanders, Oreb and Zeeb. What was I able to do compared to you?” When Gideon said this, their anger against him cooled down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon came to the Jordan and crossed over, he and the three hundred men who were with him, exhausted but still pursuing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the men of Sukkoth, “Please give some loaves of bread to the people who are following me, for they are exhausted, and I am pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, kings of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials of Sukkoth said, “Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna already in your hands that we should give bread to your army?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon said, “Because of this, when the Lord gives Zebah and Zalmunna into my hands, I will tear your bodies with desert thorns and briers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up from there to Peniel and spoke to them in the same way. The men of Peniel answered him just as the men of Sukkoth had.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he also said to the men of Peniel, “When I return safely, I will tear down this tower.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with their armies, about fifteen thousand survivors; they were all who were left of all the army of the Kedemites, for one hundred twenty thousand arms-bearing men had fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon went up on the route of the tent dwellers east of Nobah and Jogbehah and attacked the camp while the army was off guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebah and Zalmunna fled, and Gideon chased after them. He captured Zebah and Zalmunna, the two kings of Midian, and the entire army was terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon son of Joash returned from battle by the Pass of Heres.
speaker: Narrator

text: He captured a young man from among the men of Sukkoth and asked him to write the names of the leaders and elders of Sukkoth, seventy-seven men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he came to the men of Sukkoth and said, “Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me. You said, ‘Have you subjugated Zebah and Zalmunna that we should give bread to your weary army?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the city elders and disciplined the men of Sukkoth with thorns and briers of the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: He tore down the tower of Peniel and killed the men of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said to Zebah and Zalmunna, “What kind of men did you kill at Tabor?”
They said, “They were like you. Each one looked like the son of a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “They were my brothers, the sons of my mother. As the Lord lives, if you had allowed them to live, I would not kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said to his firstborn Jether, “Rise and kill them!” Yet the young man did not draw his sword because he was afraid, for he was still a young man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zebah and Zalmunna said, “You get up and attack us, for a man is judged by his strength.” So Gideon got up and killed Zebah and Zalmunna and took the crescent-shaped ornaments that were on the necks of their camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Israel said to Gideon, “Rule over us, you, and your son, and your grandson, for you have saved us from the hands of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said to them, “I will not rule over you, and my son will not rule over you. The Lord will rule over you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon continued, “I have a request to make of you, that each man would give me an earring from his spoils.” (Their enemy had golden earrings because they were Ishmaelites.)
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We will certainly give them.” So they spread out a cloak, and each man threw a ring of his spoils there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The weight of the golden earrings that he requested was seventeen hundred gold shekels. This was in addition to the crescent-shaped ornaments, jewelry, and purple clothing worn by the kings of Midian, as well as the chains hanging on the necks of their camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon used these things to make an ephod. He put it in his city, in Ophrah, and all Israel prostituted themselves to it there. It became a snare to Gideon and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Midianites were humbled before the children of Israel and did not lift their heads high again. The land had peace for forty years in the days of Gideon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerub-Baal son of Joash went to his house and lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon had seventy sons, for he had many wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: His concubine who lived in Shechem also bore him a son, and he named him Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon son of Joash died at a good old age, and he was buried in the tomb of his father Joash in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Gideon died, the children of Israel turned again to prostitute themselves with the Baals. They made Baal-Berith their god.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel did not remember the Lord their God, who had delivered them from the hands of their enemies around them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they did not keep faith with the family of Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon), for all the good he had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek son of Jerub-Baal went to Shechem, to his mother’s brothers. He spoke to them and to the house of his mother’s father saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please say in the hearing of all of the leaders of Shechem, ‘Which is better for you, to have all seventy sons of Jerub-Baal rule over you, or for one man to rule over you? Remember that I am your own flesh and bone.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So his mother’s brothers spoke all these things about him in the hearing of all the leaders of Shechem, and their hearts inclined toward Abimelek, for they said, “He is our brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him seventy silver coins from the temple of Baal-Berith. Abimelek hired unprincipled and undisciplined men, and they followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to his father’s house at Ophrah and killed his brothers, the seventy sons of Jerub-Baal, on a single stone. Yet Jotham, the youngest son of Jerub-Baal, survived because he hid himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the leaders of Shechem and everyone from Beth Millo gathered together by the oak near the pillar in Shechem to make Abimelek king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jotham heard this, he went and stood on the top of Mount Gerizim. He raised his voice and called out, saying to them, “Listen to me, leaders of Shechem, so that God may listen to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: The trees once went out to anoint a king over them. They said to the olive tree, ‘Rule over us!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet the olive tree said to them, ‘Should I stop making oil, by which God and men are honored, to go and sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So the trees said to the fig tree, ‘You come and rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet the fig tree said to them, ‘Should I stop making my sweet aroma and my fruit, to go and sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So the trees said to the grapevine, ‘You come and rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet the grapevine said to them, ‘Should I stop making my fresh wine, which cheers God and men, to go and sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So the trees said to the thorn bush, ‘You come and rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The thorn bush said to the trees, ‘If you really want to anoint me king over you, then come and take refuge in my shade. If not, let fire come out from the thorn bush and consume the cedars of Lebanon!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now then, did you show good faith and integrity when you made Abimelek king? Did you deal well with Jerub-Baal and his family? Did you do to him as his actions deserved,
speaker: Narrator

text: considering that my father waged war for you, risked his life for you, and delivered you from the hands of Midian?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you have taken a stand against my father’s family today. You killed his seventy sons, each on a single stone. You made Abimelek, son of his slave woman, king over the leaders of Shechem because he is your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you did show good faith and integrity in what you did with Jerub-Baal and his family today, then rejoice in Abimelek, and may he also rejoice in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If not, let fire come out from Abimelek and consume the leaders of Shechem and Beth Millo, and let fire come out from the leaders of Shechem and from Beth Millo and consume Abimelek!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jotham ran away and fled. He went to Beer and lived there because of Abimelek his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abimelek ruled over Israel for three years,
speaker: Narrator

text: God sent an evil spirit between Abimelek and the leaders of Shechem, and the leaders of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelek,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the violence done to the seventy sons of Jerub-Baal and their blood might come back upon Abimelek their brother, who killed them, and upon the leaders of Shechem, who empowered him to kill his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of Shechem set ambushes against him on the hilltops and robbed all who passed by them on the road. This was told to Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaal, the son of Ebed, and his brothers came to Shechem, and the leaders of Shechem trusted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out to the field, gathered and trod their grapes, and had a celebration. They went to the temple of their god and ate, drank, and cursed Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaal son of Ebed said, “Who is Abimelek, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerub-Baal, and is not Zebul his officer? Serve the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem. Why should we serve Abimelek?
speaker: Narrator

text: If only this people were under my command, I would get rid of Abimelek.” So he said to Abimelek, “Muster your army and come out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zebul the city ruler heard the words of Gaal son of Ebed and he burned with anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: He secretly sent messengers to Abimelek, saying, “Gaal, the son of Ebed, and his brothers have come to Shechem and are fortifying the city against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, get up at night, you and the people with you, and lie in wait in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning at sunrise, get up early and attack the city. He and the people with him will come out to you, then you can do to them as you find opportunity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelek and all the people who were with him got up at night and lay in wait by Shechem in four companies.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gaal son of Ebed went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate, then Abimelek and the people who were with him got up from their hiding places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gaal saw these people and said to Zebul, “Look, people are coming down from the hilltops.”
Zebul said to him, “The shadows of the hills look like men to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaal spoke again and said, “Look, people are coming down the middle of the land, and a company is coming by way of the Diviner’s Oak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zebul said to him, “Where is your mouth now, which said, ‘Who is Abimelek, that we should serve him?’ Are not these the people you dismissed out of hand? Go now, I pray, and fight against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gaal went out before the leaders of Shechem and fought Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek chased him, and Gaal fled from him. Many fell wounded at the entrance of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek stayed in Arumah, and Zebul drove out Gaal and his brothers from living in Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the people went out into the field, and this was told to Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took the people and divided them into three companies, and they laid in wait in the field. When the people came out from the city, he rose up against them and struck them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek and the company that was with him rushed forward and stood at the entrance of the city gate. The two other combat units attacked everyone in the field and struck them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek fought against the city all that day. He captured the city and killed the people inside it; he tore down the city and spread salt over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the leaders of the Tower of Shechem heard this, they entered the fortified temple of El-Berith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek was told that all the leaders of the Tower of Shechem had gathered together.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelek and all the people who were with him went up Mount Zalmon. He took an axe in his hand and cut off a tree branch, lifted it, and carried it on his shoulder. Then he said to the men who were with him, “What you have seen me do, hurry and do the same.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So everyone likewise cut off a branch and followed Abimelek. They placed them on the fortification and set the fortification on fire over them. So all the people of the Tower of Shechem died, about a thousand men and women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelek went to Thebez and encamped against Thebez and captured it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there was a fortified tower within the city, so all of the men and women and the leaders of the city fled there. They shut themselves in and went up to the top of the tower.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek came to the tower and fought against it. But as he drew near to the tower entrance to burn it with fire,
speaker: Narrator

text: a certain woman dropped an upper millstone on the head of Abimelek, and it crushed his skull.
speaker: Narrator

text: Urgently he called to the young man who carried his gear and said to him, “Draw your sword and kill me, so that people may not say about me, ‘A woman killed him.’ ” So the young man pierced him through, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Israel saw that Abimelek was dead, so everyone went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus God repaid the wickedness of Abimelek, which he committed against his father by killing his seventy brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: God also repaid the evil deeds of the men of Shechem, and the curse of Jotham son of Jerub-Baal came upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the death of Abimelek, Tola the son of Puah, the son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, arose to save Israel. He lived in Shamir, in the hill country of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He judged Israel for twenty-three years. Then he died and was buried in Shamir.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Jair the Gileadite arose and judged Israel for twenty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons who rode thirty donkeys and owned thirty cities that are in the land of Gilead. They are called Havvoth Jair to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord. They worshipped the Baals, the Ashtoreths, and the gods of Syria, Sidon, Moab, the Ammonites, and the Philistines. They abandoned the Lord and did not serve Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and He sold them into the hands of the Philistines and the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brutally oppressed the children of Israel that year. For eighteen years they oppressed all the children of Israel beyond the Jordan in the land of the Amorites in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites also crossed over the Jordan to wage war against Judah, Benjamin, and Ephraim, so that Israel was greatly distressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the children of Israel cried out to the Lord, “We have sinned against You, for we have abandoned our God and worshipped the Baals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the children of Israel, “Did I not deliver you from Egypt, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Sidonians, the Amalekites, and the Maonites when they oppressed you? You cried out to Me, and I saved you from their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you have abandoned Me and worshipped other gods. Therefore I will not save you again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and cry out to the gods that you have chosen. Let them save you in your time of distress.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the children of Israel said to the Lord, “We have sinned. Do to us whatever seems good in Your sight. Please, just deliver us today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They removed the foreign gods from among them and worshipped the Lord, and He could no longer endure the suffering of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites had been called out and set up camp in Gilead. The children of Israel assembled and set up camp in Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The commanders of Gilead said to each other, “Who is the man who will begin to fight against the Ammonites? He will be the ruler of all the inhabitants of Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty man of valor, but he was the son of a prostitute. Gilead was the father of Jephthah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gilead’s wife also bore him sons. His wife’s sons grew up and drove Jephthah away. They said to him, “You will not inherit anything from our father’s house because you are the son of another woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah fled from his brothers and lived in the land of Tob. Men of ill repute gathered around Jephthah and went out with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time passed, then the Ammonites waged war with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites waged war with Israel, the elders of Gilead went to bring Jephthah back from the land of Tob.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Jephthah, “Come and be our leader so that we may fight the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, “Did you not hate me and drive me out of my father’s house? Why have you come to me now that you are in trouble?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, “Even so, we have turned to you. Come with us and fight the Ammonites. You will be ruler over all the inhabitants of Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, “If you bring me back to wage war against the Ammonites, and the Lord gives them to me, then I will be your ruler.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, “May the Lord be a witness between us if we do not act according to your word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead. The people set him over them as ruler and leader. And Jephthah spoke all his words before the Lord in Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah sent messengers to the Ammonite king to say, “What problem is there between you and me, that you have come to me to wage war in my land?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonite king said to the messengers of Jephthah, “Because when Israel came up from Egypt, they took my land, from the Arnon to the Jabbok and as far as the Jordan. Now return it peacefully.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again Jephthah sent messengers to the Ammonite king,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said to him,
“Jephthah says this: Israel did not take the land of Moab, nor the Ammonite land;
speaker: Narrator

text: for when Israel came up from Egypt, they went into the desert as far as the Red Sea and came to Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, ‘Please let us pass through your land.’ Yet the king of Edom would not listen. They also sent messengers to the king of Moab, but he was unwilling. So Israel stayed at Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They went into the wilderness, around the lands of Edom and Moab. They went east of the land of Moab and set up camp on the other side of the River Arnon. They did not cross the boundary of Moab, for the River Arnon was the boundary of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon. Israel said to him, “Please let us pass through your land to our home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his territory, so Sihon gathered all his people and set up camp in Jahaz to fight with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord God of Israel gave Sihon and all his people into the hands of Israel, and they struck them down. So Israel took possession of all the land of the Amorites who lived in that land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took possession of all of the territory of the Amorites, from the Arnon to the Jabbok and from the desert to the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now that the Lord God of Israel has driven out the Amorites from before His people Israel, should you take it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will you not take possession of whatever Chemosh your god gives you? So everything that the Lord our God possesses before us, we will take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now are you really better than Balak son of Zippor, the king of Moab? Did he ever contend with Israel or wage war with them?
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel has lived in Heshbon and its nearby towns, in Aroer and its nearby towns, and in all the cities along the banks of the River Arnon for three hundred years. Why did you not take them back during that time?
speaker: Narrator

text: So I have not sinned against you, but it is you who are doing evil to me by waging war against me. May the Lord, the Judge, judge today between the children of Israel and the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Ammonite king would not listen to the message that Jephthah had sent him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came on Jephthah and he passed through Gilead and Manasseh, and passed through Mizpah of Gilead, and went on to the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah made a vow to the Lord, “If You will indeed give the Ammonites into my hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: then whatever comes out from the door of my house to meet me, when I return safely from the Ammonites, will surely be the Lord’s, and I will offer it up as a burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah crossed over to the Ammonites to wage war against them, and the Lord gave them into his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck them down from Aroer to Minnith, twenty cities, and as far as Abel Keramim. The defeat was very severe, and the Ammonites were humbled before the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jephthah went to his house at Mizpah, there was his daughter coming out to meet him, dancing with a tambourine. She was his only child. Other than her, he had neither son nor daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw her, he ripped up his clothes and said, “Alas, my daughter! You have brought utter disaster to me. You are my undoing, for I have given my word to the Lord, and I cannot take it back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “My father, you have opened your mouth to the Lord. Do to me what has come out of your mouth, because the Lord worked vengeance upon your enemies, the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said to her father, “Let this be done for me: Give me two months, and I and my friends will wander the hill country and mourn over my virginity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Go,” and he sent her away for two months. She and her friends went and mourned over her virginity in the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the end of two months she returned to her father, and he did to her according to the vow that he had made. She had not ever slept with a man.
So it became a custom in Israel
speaker: Narrator

text: that the women of Israel would commemorate the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite for four days each year.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Ephraim gathered together and crossed over to Zaphon. They said to Jephthah, “Why did you go to wage war with the Ammonites and not call us to go with you? We will burn down your house right on top of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to them, “My people and I were in a very great conflict with the Ammonites. I called you, but you did not save me from their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I saw that you were not going to save me, I took my life in my own hands and crossed over to the Ammonites. Then the Lord gave them into my hands. Now why have you come up to me today to wage war against me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah assembled all the men of Gilead and fought with Ephraim. The men of Gilead struck Ephraim down, for they had said, “You Gileadites are fugitives in Ephraim, living in Ephraim and Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gilead captured the fords of the Jordan River leading to Ephraim. Whenever an Ephraimite fugitive would say, “Let me cross,” the Gileadite men would say to him, “Are you an Ephraimite?” If he said, “No,”
speaker: Narrator

text: then they would say to him, “Say, ‘Shibboleth’!” Yet he would say, “Sibboleth,” for he could not pronounce it correctly. Then they would grab him and kill him at the Jordan fords. During that time forty-two thousand from Ephraim fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah judged Israel for six years. When Jephthah the Gileadite died, he was buried among the cities of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons, and he gave thirty daughters in marriage outside his clan; and he brought thirty daughters from outside for his sons. He judged Israel for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ibzan died and was buried in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, Elon the Zebulunite judged Israel. He judged Israel for ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elon the Zebulunite died and was buried in Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, Abdon son of Hillel the Pirathonite judged Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had forty sons and thirty grandsons who rode seventy donkeys. He judged Israel for eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abdon son of Hillel the Pirathonite died and was buried in Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the Amalekite hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord, so the Lord gave them into the hands of the Philistines for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a certain man from Zorah, from the tribe of Dan. His name was Manoah. His wife was infertile and had borne no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord appeared to the woman and said to her, “Indeed, you are infertile and have borne no children, yet you will conceive and bear a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now be careful, I pray, that you drink no wine or strong drink and that you do not eat anything ritually unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you will conceive and bear a son. No razor may touch his head, for the boy will be a Nazirite to God from the womb. He will begin to save Israel from the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman went to her husband and said, “A man of God came to me. He looked like a very fearsome angel of God. I did not ask him where he was from, and he did not tell me his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, ‘You will conceive and bear a son. So now, do not drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything ritually unclean, for the boy will be a Nazirite to God from the womb until the day he dies.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah prayed to the Lord, “O my Lord, let the man of God whom You sent come again to us, so that he can teach us what we should do for the boy who will be born.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God listened to the voice of Manoah, and the angel of God came again to the woman. She was sitting in the field; but her husband Manoah was not with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman hurried and ran to tell her husband, “The man who came to me the other day has appeared to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Manoah got up and went after his wife. He came to the man and said to him, “Are you the man who spoke to my wife?”
He said, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah said, “Now may your words come true! What will be the boy’s way of life and his work?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Manoah, “Your wife must observe everything that I said to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She must not consume anything that grows on the vine. She must not drink wine or strong drink, and she must not eat anything ritually unclean. She must observe everything that I commanded her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “Please let us detain you, and let us prepare a young goat for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Manoah, “If I stay, I will not eat your food, but if you want to make an offering to the Lord, you should offer it.” (For Manoah did not know that he was an angel of the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “What is your name, so that we can honor you when your words come true?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to him, “Why do you ask my name? It is too wonderful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah took the young goat and the grain offering and offered them to the Lord upon a rock. Then he did a wondrous thing while Manoah and his wife watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the flame went up from the altar toward the heavens, the angel of the Lord went up in the flames from the altar. Seeing this, Manoah and his wife fell face down on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord did not appear again to Manoah and his wife. Then Manoah knew that he was an angel of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah said to his wife, “We are certainly going to die, for we have seen God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet his wife said to him, “If the Lord wanted to kill us, He would not have taken the burnt offering and grain offering from us. He would not have shown us these things, nor let us hear things such as these at this time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman bore a son, and she called him Samson. The boy grew, and the Lord blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord began to move upon him at Mahaneh Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went down to Timnah and saw a woman from the daughters of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came back up and told his father and mother, “I have seen a woman in Timnah from the daughters of the Philistines; now get her for me as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
His father and mother said to him, “Are there no women among your relatives, or all of our people, that you are intending to take a wife from among the uncircumcised Philistines?”
Yet Samson said to his father, “Get her for me, for she pleases me well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His father and mother did not know that this was from the Lord, for He was seeking an opportunity to act against the Philistines. At that time the Philistines were ruling over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went down with his father and mother to Timnah. As they came to the vineyards of Timnah, suddenly a young lion came roaring toward him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon him, and though unarmed, he tore the lion in two as one might tear a young goat in two. However, he did not tell his father and his mother what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samson went down and spoke with the woman, and she pleased Samson.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a while, when he returned to take her, he turned aside to see the carcass of the lion. And a swarm of bees and honey were in the carcass of the lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: He scooped it out into his hands and ate it as he went along. He came to his father and mother and gave some to them, and they also ate. Yet he did not tell them he had scooped the honey out of a lion’s carcass.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his father went down to the woman. Samson put on a feast there, for this is what young men would do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines saw him, they brought thirty companions to be with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “Let me tell you a riddle. If you can explain it to me within the seven days of the feast, then I will find thirty linen robes and thirty sets of clothes to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, if you are not able to explain it to me, then you will give me thirty linen robes and thirty sets of clothes.”
They said to him, “Tell us your riddle, so we can hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them,
“Out of the eater came something to eat,
    and out of the strong came something sweet.”
They could not explain the riddle after three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day they said to Samson’s wife, “Trick your groom into telling us the riddle, or we will burn you and your father’s house with fire. Have you invited us to steal what we have? Is that not so?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Samson’s wife wept all over him and said, “You must hate me. You do not love me. You have told a riddle to the young men and did not tell it to me.”
Then he said to her, “I have not told it to my father and mother. Why should I tell it to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She wept on him for the seven days of the feast, then on the seventh day he told it to her because she had nagged him. Then she explained the riddle to her people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So on the seventh day before sunset, the men of the city said to Samson,
“What is sweeter than honey,
    and what is stronger than a lion?”
Then he said to them,
“If you had not plowed with my heifer,
    you would not have solved my riddle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord mightily came upon him, and he went down to Ashkelon and struck down thirty of their men. He took their clothes and gave them to the ones who had explained the riddle. His anger burned and he went up to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samson’s wife was given to his companion, who had been his best man.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a while, during the wheat harvest, Samson went to visit his wife, taking a young goat. He said, “I’m going in to my wife in her bedroom,” but her father would not let him go in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her father said, “I thought that you thoroughly hated her, so I gave her to your best man. Is not her younger sister better than she? Please, let her be your wife instead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “This time I cannot be blamed by the Philistines when I do them harm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went and caught three hundred foxes. He took torches and turned the foxes tail to tail and put a torch between each pair of tails.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set fire to the torches and sent the foxes into standing grain of the Philistines. He burned the harvested grain, standing grain, vineyards, and olive trees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Philistines asked, “Who did this?” They said, “Samson, the son-in-law of the Timnite, because the Timnite took the bride of Samson and gave her to his best man.”
So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “Because you have done this, I will take revenge on you, and afterwards I will stop.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck them down with a mighty blow, then went to live in a cave in Etam Rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistines went up and set up camp in Judah. They deployed against Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men of Judah said, “Why have you come up against us?”
They said, “It is to take Samson prisoner that we have come up, to do to him what he did to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So three thousand men from Judah went to the cave in Etam Rock and said to Samson, “Do you not know that the Philistines are ruling us? Why have you done this to us?”
He said to them, “As they did to me, so I have done to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to him, “We have come to take you prisoner, to give you into the hands of the Philistines.”
Samson said to them, “Swear to me that you will not attack me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “No, we will bind you securely and give you into their hands, but we will not kill you.” They bound him with two new ropes and took him away from the rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to Lehi, and the Philistines shouted as they approached him. Then the Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon him. The ropes on his arms became like burned flax and the ties on his hands dissolved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, reached out his hand and took it, and with it struck down a thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samson said,
“With a jawbone of a donkey,
    heaps upon heaps.
With a jawbone of a donkey
    I have slain a thousand men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he finished speaking, he threw the jawbone away and called that place Ramath Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was very thirsty, and he called out to the Lord, “You gave this great deliverance through Your servant, but now may I die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God split open the basin at Lehi, and water flowed out of it. He drank, was refreshed, and revived. Because of this he called the place En Hakkore, which is in Lehi to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson judged Israel for twenty years in the days of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went to Gaza. There he saw a prostitute and spent the night with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Gaza were told, “Samson has come here!” So they surrounded him and laid in wait for him all night at the city gate. They kept quiet all night, thinking, “In the morning light we will kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson lay until midnight, then at midnight he got up. He grabbed the doors of the city gate and the two gateposts and pulled them out along with the bar. He put them on his shoulder and brought them to the top of the mountain near Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Samson loved a woman in the Valley of Sorek, whose name was Delilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine rulers came up to her and said, “Trick him! Find out about how his strength is so great and how we can overcome him, bind him, and humiliate him. Each one of us will give you eleven hundred silver coins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah said to Samson, “Please tell me how your strength is so great and how you could be bound in order to be subdued.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to her, “If they bind me with seven fresh bowstrings that have not been dried, then I will become weak and be like an ordinary man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistine rulers brought her seven fresh bowstrings that had not been dried, and she bound him with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They lay in wait in her inner room. She said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson.” Then he split apart the bowstrings like a single thread is split apart at the touch of fire. So the source of his strength did not become known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Delilah said to Samson, “You have deceived me. You have told me lies. Now, please tell me how you can be bound.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “If they bind me with new ropes that have never been used, then I will become weak and be like an ordinary man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah took new ropes and bound him with them. Then she said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson.” For men were lying in wait, remaining in the room. But he split apart the ropes on his arms like a thread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Delilah said to Samson, “Up to now you have deceived me. You have told me lies. Tell how you can be bound.”
He said to her, “If you weave seven locks of my hair into the fabric on the loom and fasten it with the pin, then I will become weak and be like an ordinary man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah lulled him to sleep and wove seven locks of his hair into the fabric on the loom. She fastened it with the pin and said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson.” He awakened from his sleep and tore away from the loom pin and the fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when your heart is not with me? You have deceived me these three times and have not told me how your strength is so great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day she nagged him with her words and pleaded with him until he was tired to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he told her all his secrets and said to her, “No razor has touched my head, for I have been a Nazirite to God from my mother’s womb. If I were shaven, my strength would leave me, and I would become weak and be like all other men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Delilah saw that he had told her all his secrets, so she sent for the Philistine rulers, saying, “Come up this time, for he has told me all his secrets.” So the Philistine rulers came up to her and brought the money in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Delilah lulled Samson to sleep on her knees and called for a man to shave off the seven locks of his hair. Then she began to humiliate him, and his strength left him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She said, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson.”
Then he awakened from his sleep and thought, “I will go out as before and shake myself free of them.” He did not know that the Lord had left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines seized him and gouged out his eyes. They took him down to Gaza, bound him with bronze chains, and he ground grain in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet after it had been shaven, the hair on his head began to grow back.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine rulers gathered to offer a great sacrifice to Dagon their god and to celebrate. They said, “Our god has given Samson our enemy into our hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people saw him and praised their god, for they said,
“Our god has given into our hands
    our enemy,
the one who ruined our land
    and killed many of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When their hearts were merry, they said, “Call for Samson, so he can entertain us.” So they called for Samson from the prison, and he entertained them.
They placed him between the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to the young man who held his hand, “Let me rest and touch the pillars on which the temple is set, then I can lean against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The temple was full of men and women, and all the Philistine rulers were there. There were about three thousand men and women on the roof watching Samson entertain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson called out to the Lord, “Lord God, remember me, I pray! Please strengthen me just this once, God, so that I may get full revenge on the Philistines for my two eyes!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samson grasped the two middle pillars on which the temple was set and leaned against them, one with his right hand and one with his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said, “Let me die with the Philistines!” He pushed with all his strength, and the temple fell upon the rulers and all the people who were in it. At his death he killed more than he had killed in his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers and all his family came down, carried him, brought him up, and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the grave of his father Manoah. He had judged Israel for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man from the hill country of Ephraim whose name was Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
