He said to his mother, “The eleven hundred shekels of silver that were taken from you, on which you put a curse, even speaking the curse in my ears—here is the silver with me. I took it.”
Then his mother said, “May the Lord bless my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he returned the eleven hundred silver coins to his mother. His mother said, “I certainly consecrated the silver to the Lord, for my son to make a carved idol and a metal idol, so now I return it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he returned the silver to his mother, she took two hundred shekels of silver and gave them to a silversmith to make a carved idol and a metal idol. And they were put in the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man Micah owned a shrine. He made an ephod and household idols, and he hired one of his sons to be a priest for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days there was no king in Israel. Everyone did what was right in his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a young man from Bethlehem in Judah. He was a Levite from Judah, and he stayed as a resident foreigner there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man went from the city of Bethlehem in Judah to stay wherever he could find a place. He came to the hill country of Ephraim, to the house of Micah, to do his work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Micah said to him, “Where do you come from?”
He said to him, “I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I am going to stay wherever I can find a place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah said to him, “Live with me, and be a father and a priest for me. I will give you ten silver coins a year, a set of clothes, and food.” So the Levite went in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levite decided to live with the man, and the young man became like one of his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah ordained the Levite, and the young man became his priest and lived in the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Micah said, “Now I know that the Lord will do good for me, for I have a Levite to be my priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
In those days there was no king in Israel.
And in those days the tribe of the Danites was looking for an inheritance in which to live, for no territory had come into their possession among the tribes of Israel up to that time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the children of Dan sent out from their families five valorous men from Zorah and Eshtaol in order to spy out and explore the land. They said to them, “Go, explore the land.”
They came to the hill country of Ephraim, to the house of Micah, and they spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were at the house of Micah, they noticed the speech of the young Levite. They turned aside and said to him, “Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place? What is your business here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them what Micah had done for him, saying, “He hired me, and I became his priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Please ask God if we may know whether our mission will be a success as we go to do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest said to them, “Go in peace. The Lord is watching the way you are going.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The five men went away and came to Laish. They saw the people who were there, living securely according to the culture of the Sidonians. There were no rulers in the land who might put them to shame for anything. They were far from the Sidonians and had no ties with anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came back to their brothers in Zorah and Eshtaol, their brothers asked them, “What do you have to say?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Get up! Let us go up against them, for we have seen the land. It is very good. You are silent, but do not hesitate to go to take the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go, you will come to a secure people and to an expansive land. For God has given it into your hands: a place where there is no lack of anything on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So six hundred fully armed men set out from the family of the Danites, from Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up and set up camp in Kiriath Jearim in Judah. Therefore they call that place Mahaneh Dan to this day. It is west of Kiriath Jearim.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they passed the hill country of Ephraim and came to the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five men who went to spy out the land of Laish said to their brothers, “Did you know that in these houses are an ephod, household idols, a carved image, and a metal idol? Now think about what to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they turned aside there and came to the house of the young Levite, to the house of Micah, and greeted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The six hundred men armed with their weapons of war, who were the children of Dan, stood at the entrance to the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five men who went to spy out the land went in and took the carved idol, ephod, household idols, and the metal idol. The priest was standing at the entrance to the gate with the six hundred fully armed men.
speaker: Narrator

text: When these men went into the house of Micah and took the carved idol, ephod, household idols, and the metal idol, the priest said to them, “What are you doing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Quiet! Put your hand over your mouth and go with us. Be a father and priest for us. Is it better to be a priest for one man’s house or for a tribe and a family in Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest’s heart was glad. He took the ephod, the household idols, and the carved image and went among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they turned and left, putting the children, livestock, and valuables in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had gone far from the house of Micah, but the neighbors of Micah assembled and caught up to the children of Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They called out to the children of Dan. So they turned and said to Micah, “What is wrong that have you assembled together?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You took the gods that I made, and the priest, and then you left. What do I have left? So what is this that you say to me, ‘What is wrong?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Dan said to him, “Do not let us hear your voice again. Otherwise bitter men might meet you and you will forfeit your life and the lives of your family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the children of Dan went their way. And when Micah saw that they were too strong for him, he turned and went back to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took what Micah had made and his priest, and came to Laish to a quiet and secure people. They struck them down with the edge of the sword and burned the city with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There was no one to save them because the city was far from Sidon and had no contact with anyone. It was in the valley by Beth Rehob.
They rebuilt the city and lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They called the city Dan, after their father Dan, who was born to Israel (Laish was the former name of the city).
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Dan set up the carved idol for themselves. Jonathan the son of Gershom, the son of Manasseh, and his sons were priests to the tribe of Dan until the time of exile from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they displayed Micah’s graven image that he had made, for the whole time that the house of God was in Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, when there was no king in Israel, there was a certain Levite living as resident foreigner in a remote part of the hill country of Ephraim. He took a concubine for himself from Bethlehem in Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet his concubine became angry with him and went away from him to her father’s house at Bethlehem in Judah. She was there for four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband got up and went after her in order to speak tenderly to her and bring her back. His servant and two donkeys were with him. When he came to her father’s house, the girl’s father saw him and was happy to meet with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father-in-law, the girl’s father, prevailed upon him to stay with him for three days. So they ate and drank and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day they woke up early in the morning. He got ready to go, but the girl’s father said to his son-in-law, “Strengthen yourself with a little food, and then you can go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the two of them sat down to eat and drink together. Then the girl’s father said to the man, “Please spend the night and let your heart be merry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man got up to go, but his father-in-law urged him until he turned back and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He got up early in the morning on the fifth day to go. The girl’s father said, “Please, strengthen yourself and wait until later in the day.” So the two of them ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man got up to go: he, his concubine, and his servant. His father-in-law, the girl’s father, said to him, “Look! It is getting dark. Spend the night! Settle in and spend the night here, let your heart be merry. You can get up early tomorrow and go home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the man did not want to spend the night, so he got up and left and approached Jebus (that is, Jerusalem). Two saddled donkeys and his concubine were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were near Jebus, it was getting very late. The servant said to his master, “Come, let us turn aside to this Jebusite city and spend the night in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His master said to him, “We must not turn aside to a city of foreigners, who are not children of Israel. We will continue on to Gibeah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his servant, “Come, let us go to one of these places. We will spend the night in Gibeah or Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They continued and went on. The sun went down when they were near Gibeah in Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they turned aside there to go and spend the night in Gibeah. They went in and sat in the city square, but no one took them in to spend the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, an old man came in at evening time from his work in the field. The man was from the hill country of Ephraim and lived as a resident foreigner in Gibeah, but the townspeople were Benjamites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked up and saw the traveler in the city square. The old man said, “Where are you going, and where do you come from?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “We are traveling from Bethlehem in Judah to a remote part of the hill country of Ephraim. I am from there. I went to Bethlehem in Judah, and now I am going to the house of the Lord. No one has taken me into his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet there is enough straw and fodder for our donkeys, with bread and wine for me, your maidservant, and the young man who is with your servant. We do not lack anything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The old man said, “Do not worry. I will take care of whatever you need. Just do not spend the night in the city square.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought him into his house and gave food to his donkeys. They washed their feet, ate, and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were enjoying themselves, the men of the city, who were wicked men, surrounded the house and pounded on the door. They said to the old man, the master of the house, “Bring out the man who came to your house, so we can have relations with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The master of the house went out to them and said, “No, my brothers, do not commit this evil act, not after this man has come into my house. Do not commit this disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here are my virgin daughter and the man’s concubine. Let me bring them out to you. Ravish them and do to them what you please. But do not commit this vile act against this man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men were unwilling to listen to him, so the man seized his concubine and brought her out to them in the street. They knew her and abused her all night until morning. As the dawn began to break, they let her go.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman came back at daybreak and fell down at the door of the man’s house where her master was, lying there until it was light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her master got up in the morning and opened the doors of the house. He went out to go on his way, but there was the woman, his concubine, fallen at the door of the house with her hands on the threshold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “Get up, let us be going,” but there was no answer. So the man put her on a donkey and went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he got home, he took a knife and seized his concubine, then cut her body into twelve pieces. Then he sent her throughout all the territory of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who saw this said, “Nothing like this has been done or seen since the day the children of Israel came out of the land of Egypt until today. Consider it, take counsel, and speak up!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the children of Israel from Dan to Beersheba, and also from the land of Gilead, went out and gathered together in an assembly as one man before the Lord at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of all the people from all the tribes of Israel presented themselves in an assembly of the people of God, who numbered four hundred thousand infantrymen bearing swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Benjamites heard that the children of Israel had gone up to Mizpah.) The children of Israel said, “Tell how this evil happened!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, answered, “My concubine and I came to Gibeah, in Benjamin, to spend the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of Gibeah rose up against me. At night they surrounded the house where I was staying. They wanted to kill me; instead they ravished my concubine so that she died.
speaker: Narrator

text: I seized my concubine, cut her into pieces, and sent her throughout all the territory of Israel, because they committed an infamous and disgraceful act in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, all of you are children of Israel. Give your advice and counsel here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people arose as one man and said, “Not a man among us will go to his tent, and no one will turn aside to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this is what we will do to Gibeah. We will go against it by lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will take ten men out of every hundred, from every tribe of Israel, a hundred from every thousand, and a thousand from every ten thousand, to bring provisions for the troops. Then when they come to Gibeah in Benjamin, they may repay them for all the evil that they committed in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men of Israel gathered at the city, united like one man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribes of Israel sent men throughout the whole tribe of Benjamin, saying, “What is this evil that has been committed among you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now hand over the wicked men in Gibeah, so that we can kill them and purge the evil from Israel.”
Yet the Benjamites were not willing to listen to their fellow children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Benjamites gathered from their cities at Gibeah in order to go out and wage war against the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day, the Benjamites mustered twenty-six thousand armed men from the cities and seven hundred specially chosen men from Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of all these people there were seven hundred specially chosen men who were left-handed, all of whom could sling a stone at a hair and not miss.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel, apart from Benjamin, gathered four hundred thousand armed men who drew the sword; all of them were men of war.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Israel arose, went up to Bethel, and asked God, “Who should go up first to wage war against the Benjamites?”
The Lord said, “Judah first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel got up in the morning and camped against Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel went out for battle with Benjamin, and the men of Israel lined up for battle at Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Benjamites came out from Gibeah and struck twenty-two thousand Israelite men down to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people, the men of Israel, rallied and lined up for battle again in the place where they had lined up on the first day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the children of Israel went up and wept before the Lord until evening. They asked the Lord, “Should we advance and fight our brother-tribesmen the Benjamites again?”
The Lord said, “Advance against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the children of Israel advanced against the Benjamites for the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the second day, the Benjamites went out from Gibeah to meet them and again struck eighteen thousand men down to the ground, every one of them armed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the children of Israel, all the people, went up to Bethel where they wept and sat before the Lord. They fasted that day until evening and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel asked the Lord (because the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Phinehas the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stood before it then), “Should we go out again to wage war with our brother-tribesmen the Benjamites, or should we not?”
The Lord said, “Go up, for tomorrow I will give them into your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel set an ambushing force around Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel went up against the Benjamites on the third day and lined up at Gibeah as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Benjamites went out to engage the people and were drawn away from the city. They began to strike the people down as before. On the main roads that go up to Bethel and Gibeah and in the field, they struck down about thirty children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Benjamites said, “They are struck down before us like at the beginning.” But the children of Israel said, “Let us retreat and draw them away from the city toward the main roads.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men of Israel rose up out of their place and assumed their battle positions at Baal Tamar. Then the men of Israel in ambush charged out of their places, out of the meadows of Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ten thousand specially chosen men from all of Israel came against Gibeah. The battle was fierce, and the Benjamites did not know that disaster was upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord defeated Benjamin before Israel, and that day the children of Israel struck down twenty-five thousand one hundred Benjamites, every one of them armed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Benjamites saw that they were defeated.
Now the men of Israel had withdrawn from Benjamin, because they relied on the men in ambush whom they had set against Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the ambushing force rushed on and attacked Gibeah. They struck down the whole city with the edge of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel had made an agreement with the ambushing force that when they sent up a large amount of smoke from the city,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the children of Israel would turn around in battle.
When the Benjamites had begun to strike the children of Israel down, about thirty men, they said, “Surely they are struck down before us like at the beginning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet when the smoke began to rise up from the city in a column, the Benjamites looked behind them and suddenly noticed the whole city going up in smoke to the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Israel turned around, and the men of Benjamin were horrified because they saw that disaster had come on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they fled from the men of Israel toward the direction of the wilderness, but the battle overtook them. Whoever came out of the cities destroyed them in their midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: They surrounded the Benjamites, chased them without rest, and trampled them down near Gibeah toward the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eighteen thousand men from Benjamin fell; all these were men of valor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest turned and fled toward the wilderness to Rimmon Rock, and they cut down five thousand men on the main roads. They pursued them relentlessly until they reached Gidom and killed two thousand of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Benjamites who fell that day numbered twenty-five thousand, every one of them armed, valorous men.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, six hundred men turned and fled toward the wilderness, to Rimmon Rock. They dwelled at Rimmon Rock for four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the men of Israel turned back against the Benjamites and struck them with the edge of the sword—city inhabitants, animals, and everything that could be found. Indeed, they set on fire every city that could be found.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Mizpah the men of Israel had taken an oath: “No one among us will give his daughter to a Benjamite as his wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people came to Bethel and sat there before God until evening. They raised their voices and wept, sobbing loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Why, Lord God of Israel, has this happened in Israel, that today a tribe is missing from Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning the people got up early and built an altar there. They offered burnt offerings and peace offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel said, “Who from all the tribes of Israel did not go up with the assembly to the Lord?” For they vowed a solemn oath regarding whoever did not go up to the Lord at Mizpah stating, “He must be killed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel lamented for Benjamin their brother, and said, “One tribe is cut off from Israel today.
speaker: Narrator

text: What can we do to find wives for those who are left? For we swore by the Lord not to give them our daughters as wives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said, “Is there anyone from among the tribes of Israel who did not go up to the Lord at Mizpah?” Then they learned that no one from the camp of Jabesh Gilead had come to the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people were counted, indeed, there was not a man there from among the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the assembly sent twelve thousand valorous men there and commanded them, “Go and strike down the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead with the edge of the sword, including women and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you will do: You will kill every man and every woman who has slept with a man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So among the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead they found four hundred young virgins who had never slept with a man, and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the whole assembly sent someone to speak to the Benjamites who were at Rimmon Rock, and they declared peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Benjamites returned at that time, and they gave to them the women who were still alive from among the women of Jabesh Gilead. Yet they did not find enough for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people felt sorry for Benjamin, for the Lord had made a gap among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of the assembly said, “What can we do to find wives for those who are left? The Benjamite women were destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “There must be an inheritance for the remnant of Benjamin, so that a tribe will not be wiped out from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet we cannot give them our daughters for wives, for the children of Israel swore, ‘Cursed be anyone who gives a wife to Benjamin.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Wait! There is an annual festival of the Lord in Shiloh, which is north of Bethel, east of the main road that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they commanded the Benjamites, “Go and hide in the vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Watch, and then when the daughters of Shiloh come out to dance in the dances, come out from the vineyards and have every man grab a wife for himself from among the daughters of Shiloh. Then go to the land of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: When their fathers or their brothers come to us to complain, we will say to them, ‘Be favorable to them for our sakes, because we did not take for each man a wife in the battle; for you have not given women to them at the time, thereby making yourselves guilty.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Benjamites did this. They carried away wives for each man from among the dancers that they caught. Then they returned to their inheritance, rebuilt the cities, and lived in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, the children of Israel departed from there each man to his tribe and to his family. They went out from there to their own inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days there was no king in Israel; everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator
